elements.content: Hydrothermal reactions of Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O with two new triazine-based phosphonic acids, 2,4,6-triglyphosate-1,3,5-triazine (H9L1) and 4,6-biglyphosate-2-hydroxyl-1,3,5-triazine (H6L2), afforded two new zinc phosphonates, namely, [(C5H14N2)­Zn3(HL1)­(H2O)]·3.5H2O (1) and [(C5H14N2)­Zn2L2]·3H2O (2), respectively. The two zinc phosphonates were structurally characterized through single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 is a three-dimensional (3D) framework in that Zn–O–P chains are connected by HL18– anions with hendecadentate modes. In compound 2, each L26– anion links four Zn2 binuclear units to form a 3D framework. In both compounds 1 and 2, the protonated 2-methylpiperazines are encapsulated into the channels of 3D frameworks. Thermogravimetric analysis and powder X-ray diffraction reveal that compounds 1 and 2 are thermally stable up to 200 and 160 °C under an air atmosphere, respectively. Compounds 1 and 2 display near-UV and purple luminescence with maximal bands at 377 and 402 nm, respectively. It worth noting that the luminescence of solids 1 and 2 can be preserved after compounds 1 and 2 are heated at 200 and 160 °C for 2 h under an air atmosphere, respectively. In addition, the ion-exchange property of compound 1 was also studied.

elements.content: Metal phosphonates are of great research interest because of their structural and compositional diversity, as well as their thermal and chemical stability for potential applications as porous materials, ion exchangers, proton conductors, Langmuir–Blodgett films, nonlinear optics, molecular sensors, catalysts, magnets, etc. Because of the low solubility and crystallinity of metal phosphonates, it is still difficult to grow single crystals of a suitable size and high quality for X-ray structural analysis. In recent years, much effort has been devoted to modifying phosphonic acids with additional groups, including amino, carboxylate, pyridyl, triazole, thienyl, and imidazole groups. This is due to the fact that additional groups can enrich coordination modes to improve the solubility and crystallinity of metal phosphonates. As a result, a variety of intriguing metal phosphonates have been obtained and structurally characterized, such as calcium phosphonates with tuned proton conductivity. On the other hand, triazine derivatives have been widely exploited to construct interesting coordination polymers, especially flexible polycarboxylate groups connecting with triazine rings. However, triazine rings with phosphonate groups have been rarely reported in previous work. Recently, an effect method has been used to synthesize functionalized phosphonic acids by a combination of the N­(CH2COOH) (CH2PO3H2) moiety and other organic groups. On the basis of these functionalized phosphonate ligands, many luminescent metal phosphonates with three-dimensional (3D) frameworks, hybrid layers or polynuclear clusters, have been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. In this regard, we suggest that the combination of the N­(CH2COOH) (CH2PO3H2) moiety and triazine rings would result in new functionalized phosphonate ligands. Thus, two new triazine-based phosphonic acids, 2,4,6-triglyphosate-1,3,5-triazine [H9L1 ()] and 4,6-biglyphosate-2-hydroxyl-1,3,5-triazine [H6L2 ()], have been successfully synthesized. Remarkably, ligands H9L1 and H6L2 possess 21 and 16 coordination sites, respectively. Such new multifunctional phosphonate ligands would adopt diversified coordination modes to form many interesting metal phosphonates. Herein, we report the synthesis, crystal structures, thermal stabilities, luminescence, and ion-exchange property of two new 3D zinc phosphonates: [(C5H14N2)­Zn3(HL1)­(H2O)]·3.5H2O (1) and [(C5H14N2)­Zn2L2]·3H2O (2).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal phosphonates are of great research interest because of their structural and compositional diversity, as well as their thermal and chemical stability for potential applications as porous materials, ion exchangers, proton conductors, Langmuir-Blodgett films, nonlinear optics, molecular sensors, catalysts, magnets, etc. Because of the low solubility and crystallinity of metal phosphonates, it is still difficult to grow single crystals of a suitable size and high quality for X-ray structural analysis. In recent years, much effort has been devoted to modifying phosphonic acids with additional groups, including amino, carboxylate, pyridyl, triazole, thienyl, and imidazole groups. This is due to the fact that additional groups can enrich coordination modes to improve the solubility and crystallinity of metal phosphonates. As a result, a variety of intriguing metal phosphonates have been obtained and structurally characterized, such as calcium phosphonates with tuned proton conductivity. On the other hand, triazine derivatives have been widely exploited to construct interesting coordination polymers, especially flexible polycarboxylate groups connecting with triazine rings. However, triazine rings with phosphonate groups have been rarely reported in previous work. Recently, an effect method has been used to synthesize functionalized phosphonic acids by a combination of the N(CH2COOH) (CH2PO3H2) moiety and other organic groups. On the basis of these functionalized phosphonate ligands, many luminescent metal phosphonates with three-dimensional (3D) frameworks, hybrid layers or polynuclear clusters, have been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. In this regard, we suggest that the combination of the N(CH2COOH) (CH2PO3H2) moiety and triazine rings would result in new functionalized phosphonate ligands. Thus, two new triazine-based phosphonic acids, 2,4,6-triglyphosate-1,3,5-triazine [H9L1 ()] and 4,6-biglyphosate-2-hydroxyl-1,3,5-triazine [H6L2 ()], have been successfully synthesized. Remarkably, ligands H9L1 and H6L2 possess 21 and 16 coordination sites, respectively. Such new multifunctional phosphonate ligands would adopt diversified coordination modes to form many interesting metal phosphonates. Herein, we report the synthesis, crystal structures, thermal stabilities, luminescence, and ion-exchange property of two new 3D zinc phosphonates: [(C5H14N2)Zn3(HL1)(H2O)]⋅3.5H2O (1) and [(C5H14N2)Zn2L2]⋅3H2O (2).

elements.content: Phosphonate ligands H9L1 and H6L2 were prepared according to the methods reported previously. Other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Elemental (C, H, N) analyses were conducted with a Vario EL III element analyzer, while metal contents were tested using an Ultrimas ICP spectrometer. Infrared spectra were obtained on Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR and VERTEX 70 FT-IR spectrometers. The emission and excitation spectra were recorded in the solid state at room temperature with a model F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer, while the lifetime and quantum yield were investigated in the solid state with an Edinburgh model FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Netzsch STA449C instrument at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 from room temperature to 1000 °C under an air gas flow. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired on DMAX-2500 and Ultima IV diffractometers using Cu Kα radiation in an ambient environment.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General

Phosphonate ligands H9L1 and H6L2 were prepared according to the methods reported previously. Other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Elemental (C, H, N) analyses were conducted with a Vario EL III element analyzer, while metal contents were tested using an Ultrimas ICP spectrometer. Infrared spectra were obtained on Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR and VERTEX 70 FT-IR spectrometers. The emission and excitation spectra were recorded in the solid state at room temperature with a model F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer, while the lifetime and quantum yield were investigated in the solid state with an Edinburgh model FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Netzsch STA449C instrument at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 from room temperature to 1000 °C under an air gas flow. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired on DMAX-2500 and Ultima IV diffractometers using Cu Kα radiation in an ambient environment.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.1021 g, 0.4651 mmol), H9L1 (0.0591 g, 0.102 mmol), and 2-methylpiperazine (1.00 g, 9.98 mmol) in 8.0 mL of distilled water with the pH value adjusted to around 3.9 was sealed in a Parr Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 110 °C for 120 h. After the sample had been slowly cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals were obtained as a homogeneous phase based on powder XRD patterns. Yield: 0.0254 g (26%). Anal. elements.content: Newly synthesized powder of 1 (0.0281 g, 0.0295 mmol) was added to a solution containing AgNO3 (0.1690 g, 1.00 mmol) and 5.0 mL of ethanol. Then, the mixture was sealed into a Parr Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 80 °C for 20 h. After the sample had been cooled to room temperature, the final product was filtered, washed with 3 × 50 mL of distilled water and then 3 × 50 mL of ethanol, and dried at ambient temperature. Ion-Exchange Experiment

Synthesis of 1-Ag 

Newly synthesized powder of 1 (0.0281 g, 0.0295 mmol) was added to a solution containing AgNO3 (0.1690 g, 1.00 mmol) and 5.0 mL of ethanol. Then, the mixture was sealed into a Parr Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 80 °C for 20 h. After the sample had been cooled to room temperature, the final product was filtered, washed with 3 × 50 mL of distilled water and then 3 × 50 mL of ethanol, and dried at ambient temperature. ICP analysis shows that the content of Ag+ in solid 1-Ag is 0.151 mmol g-1. Elemental analyses: C, 20.34; H, 3.72; N, 11.26.

elements.content: Newly synthesized powder of 1 (0.0414 g, 0.0434 mmol) was soaked in a solution containing CuCl2·2H2O (1.7004 g, 9.9771 mmol) and 5.0 mL of distilled water for 18 days. The color of the powder turned from white into green. After filtration, the green powder was washed with a vast amount of distilled water until the filter liquor was colorless and then dried at ambient temperature. ICP analysis shows that the content of Cu2+ in solid 1-Cu is 1.803 mmol g–1. Elemental analyses: C, 17.72; H, 3.76; N, 9.94.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1-Cu 

Newly synthesized powder of 1 (0.0414 g, 0.0434 mmol) was soaked in a solution containing CuCl2⋅2H2O (1.7004 g, 9.9771 mmol) and 5.0 mL of distilled water for 18 days. The color of the powder turned from white into green. After filtration, the green powder was washed with a vast amount of distilled water until the filter liquor was colorless and then dried at ambient temperature. ICP analysis shows that the content of Cu2+ in solid 1-Cu is 1.803 mmol g-1. Elemental analyses: C, 17.72; H, 3.76; N, 9.94.

elements.content: X-ray data for compounds 1 and 2 were collected at 293(2) K on a Rigaku Mercury CCD/AFC diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation [λ­(Mo Kα) = 0.71073 Å]. Data of compounds 1 and 2 were reduced with CrystalClear version 1.3. Their structures were determined by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 using SHELXTL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were treated anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms that bonded to carbon and nitrogen atoms, as well as hydrogen of carboxylate, were generated geometrically, while no attemps were performed to locate hydrogen atoms of water molecules and hydroxyl, or hydrogen atoms of protonated 2-methylpiperazine in 2. Crystallographic data for compounds 1 and 2 are summarized in . Selected bond lengths and angles for compounds 1 and 2 are listed in and , respectively. CCDC 1409896 (1) and 1409897 (2).

Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized through the reaction of Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O, 2-methylpiperazine, H9L1, and H6L2 under hydrothermal conditions. Powder XRD patterns of compounds 1 and 2 are in agreement with those of simulated single-crystal X-ray data. Furthermore, elemental analyses of compounds 1 and 2 are also in accord with respective calculated values. These results suggest that final products of compounds 1 and 2 are in the homogeneous phase.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized through the reaction of Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O, 2-methylpiperazine, H9L1, and H6L2 under hydrothermal conditions. Powder XRD patterns of compounds 1 and 2 are in agreement with those of simulated single-crystal X-ray data. Furthermore, elemental analyses of compounds 1 and 2 are also in accord with respective calculated values. These results suggest that final products of compounds 1 and 2 are in the homogeneous phase.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that the asymmetric unit of 1 contains three crystallographically independent Zn­(II) ions, one HL18– anion, one protonated 2-methylpiperazine, one coordinated water molecule, and 3.5 free water molecules (a). Zn1 is in a distorted [ZnO4] tetrahedral coordination geometry, which is defined by four phosphonate oxygen atoms from four different HL18– anions. Zn2 is surrounded by three HL18– anions in a distorted [ZnO4] tetrahedral coordination geometry. One HL18– anion chelates to Zn2 through two phosphonate oxygen atoms (O2 and O11), resulting in a 12-membered ring (Zn–O–P–C–N–C–N–C–N–C–P–O). The other two HL18– anions interacted with Zn2 through two other phosphonate oxygen atoms (O3b and O8a). Zn3 is surrounded by two HL18– anions and one coordinated water molecule (O16) in a distorted [ZnO4] tetrahedral coordination geometry. One HL18– anion chelates to Zn3 through one phosphonate oxygen atom (O7) and one carboxylate oxygen atom (O9), resulting in an eight-membered ring (Zn–O–P–C–N–C–C–O), while the other HL18– anion interacted with Zn3 through one other carboxylate oxygen atom (O4d). The Zn–O bond lengths are in the range of 1.862(8)–1.992(8) Å, which are comparable with those of other reported zinc phosphonates.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Descriptions

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that the asymmetric unit of 1 contains three crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions, one HL18- anion, one protonated 2-methylpiperazine, one coordinated water molecule, and 3.5 free water molecules (a). Zn1 is in a distorted [ZnO4] tetrahedral coordination geometry, which is defined by four phosphonate oxygen atoms from four different HL18- anions. Zn2 is surrounded by three HL18- anions in a distorted [ZnO4] tetrahedral coordination geometry. One HL18- anion chelates to Zn2 through two phosphonate oxygen atoms (O2 and O11), resulting in a 12-membered ring (Zn-O-P-C-N-C-N-C-N-C-P-O). The other two HL18- anions interacted with Zn2 through two other phosphonate oxygen atoms (O3b and O8a). Zn3 is surrounded by two HL18- anions and one coordinated water molecule (O16) in a distorted [ZnO4] tetrahedral coordination geometry. One HL18- anion chelates to Zn3 through one phosphonate oxygen atom (O7) and one carboxylate oxygen atom (O9), resulting in an eight-membered ring (Zn-O-P-C-N-C-C-O), while the other HL18- anion interacted with Zn3 through one other carboxylate oxygen atom (O4d). The Zn-O bond lengths are in the range of 1.862(8)-1.992(8) Å, which are comparable with those of other reported zinc phosphonates.

elements.content: On the other hand, the HL18– anion exhibits a hendecadentate mode to combine nine Zn­(II) ions through nine phosphonates and two carboxylate oxygen atoms (b). To the best of our knowledge, the coordination number of the HL18– anion is larger than those of triazine-based carboxylate ligands. The protonated carboxylate atom (O14) provides one hydrogen atom to form a strong hydrogen bond with another carboxylate atom [O14···O10e, 2.547(11) Å], while protonated 2-methylpiperazine provides three hydrogen atoms to form three hydrogen bonds with phosphonate oxygen atoms [N7···O7f, 2.809(16) Å; N8···O3, 2.989(17) Å; N8···O12, 2.930(19) Å]. Meanwhile, the protonated 2-methylpiperazine also hydrogen bonds with one free water molecule [N7···O20, 2.87(6) Å].

elements.content: As shown in c, [Zn1O4] and [Zn2O4] tetrahedra are bridged by [P1CO3] and [P2CO3] tetrahedra through corner sharing, and [Zn3O4] tetrahedra interact with [Zn1O4] and [Zn2O4] tetrahedra via [P3CO3] tetrahedra through corner sharing. As a result, a wavelike Zn–O–P chain along the a axis is formed. The Zn–O–P chains are further cross-linked by HL18– anions into a 3D framework (d,e). The 3D framework contains two types of channels along the a and c axes. The protonated 2-methylpiperazines are encapsulated into the channels through the hydrogen bonds mentioned above between the protonated nitrogen atoms and phosphonate oxygen atoms.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of one Zn­(II) ion, one-half of an L26– anion, a half-protonated 2-methylpiperazine, and 1.5 free water molecules (a). Zn1 is surrounded by three L26– anions in a distorted [O3ZnN] tetrahedral coordination geometry. One L26– anion chelates to Zn1 through one phosphonate oxygen atom (O1) and a nitrogen donor (N2) of the triazine ring, resulting in a seven-membered ring (Zn–O–P–C–N–C–N), while the other two L26– anions contact Zn1 via one phosphonate oxygen atom (O2a) and one carboxylate oxygen atom (O4b). The Zn–O bond lengths are in the range of 1.942(4)–1.971(4) Å, which are comparable with those of other reported zinc phosphonates. The Zn1–N2 bond length is 2.022(4) Å. On the other hand, each L26– anion exhibits an octadentate mode to combine six Zn­(II) ions through four phosphonates and two carboxylate oxygen atoms, as well as two nitrogen donors of the triazine ring. This is obviously different from those in compound 1, in that the nitrogen donors of the triazine ring do not take part in coordination. As shown in b, two neighboring Zn­(II) ions are bridged by two O–P–O groups to form a binuclear unit. Each L26– anion connects four neighboring binuclear units. Thus, such binuclear units are cross-linked by L26– anions into a 3D framework (c).

elements.content: TGA and powder XRD measurements were taken to examine thermal stabilities (). For solid 1, an obvious stage occurs from room temperature to 150 °C with a 10.5% weight loss, which is attributed to the loss of 4.5 water molecules per formula (calculated value of 9.1%). When the sample is heated further, small weight losses appear until an abrupt stage starts from 290 °C due to the decomposition of the HL18– anion and the protonated 2-methylpiperazine. As a result, the 3D framework collapses. A TGA curve of solid 2 indicates that there is an obvious stage in the temperature range of 40–160 °C with a 7.87% observed weight loss, which corresponds with the release of three free water molecules per formula (calculated value of 7.58%). Then, the subsequent weight loss over 300 °C is assigned to the decomposition of the L26– anion and the protonated 2-methylpiperazine, resulting in the collapse of the 3D framework. Furthermore, powder XRD patterns of solids 1-200 and 2-160 are essentially in agreement with those of as-prepared 1 and 2, respectively. These results indicate that the 3D frameworks of compounds 1 and 2 are stable up to 200 and 160 °C, respectively, under an air atmosphere.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stabilities

TGA and powder XRD measurements were taken to examine thermal stabilities (). For solid 1, an obvious stage occurs from room temperature to 150 °C with a 10.5% weight loss, which is attributed to the loss of 4.5 water molecules per formula (calculated value of 9.1%). When the sample is heated further, small weight losses appear until an abrupt stage starts from 290 °C due to the decomposition of the HL18- anion and the protonated 2-methylpiperazine. As a result, the 3D framework collapses. A TGA curve of solid 2 indicates that there is an obvious stage in the temperature range of 40-160 °C with a 7.87% observed weight loss, which corresponds with the release of three free water molecules per formula (calculated value of 7.58%). Then, the subsequent weight loss over 300 °C is assigned to the decomposition of the L26- anion and the protonated 2-methylpiperazine, resulting in the collapse of the 3D framework. Furthermore, powder XRD patterns of solids 1-200 and 2-160 are essentially in agreement with those of as-prepared 1 and 2, respectively. These results indicate that the 3D frameworks of compounds 1 and 2 are stable up to 200 and 160 °C, respectively, under an air atmosphere.

elements.content: Solid-state luminescent properties were investigated at ambient temperature. Solid 1 displays near-ultraviolet (UV) luminescence with a maximal band at 377 nm (). The external quantum yield reaches 2.9% upon excitation at 293 nm. Because both emission and excitation profiles of solid 1 are similar to those of H9L1, the UV emission of solid 1 may be assigned to a ligand-centered π–π* transition. The emission peak of solid 1 shows a 17 nm bathochromic shift in comparison with that of H9L1. Solid 1-200 can also display similar UV emission with a maximal band at 363 nm. This result is in accord with the observation that the 3D framework of solid 1 is stable up to 200 °C under an air atmosphere. Although the structure of solid 1-250 disagrees with that of as-prepared 1, solid 1-250 can also emit similar near-UV luminescence. This indicates that the near-UV luminescence can be preserved after compound 1 is heated at 250 °C for 2 h under an air atmosphere. In addition, solid 1 can display more strong near-UV luminescence with a maximal band at 367 nm at 10 K.

Luminescenct Properties

Solid-state luminescent properties were investigated at ambient temperature. Solid 1 displays near-ultraviolet (UV) luminescence with a maximal band at 377 nm (). The external quantum yield reaches 2.9% upon excitation at 293 nm. Because both emission and excitation profiles of solid 1 are similar to those of H9L1, the UV emission of solid 1 may be assigned to a ligand-centered π-π* transition. The emission peak of solid 1 shows a 17 nm bathochromic shift in comparison with that of H9L1. Solid 1-200 can also display similar UV emission with a maximal band at 363 nm. This result is in accord with the observation that the 3D framework of solid 1 is stable up to 200 °C under an air atmosphere. Although the structure of solid 1-250 disagrees with that of as-prepared 1, solid 1-250 can also emit similar near-UV luminescence. This indicates that the near-UV luminescence can be preserved after compound 1 is heated at 250 °C for 2 h under an air atmosphere. In addition, solid 1 can display more strong near-UV luminescence with a maximal band at 367 nm at 10 K.

elements.content: Solid 2 displays purple luminescence with a maximal band at 402 nm via excitation at 273 nm (). The external quantum yield reaches 9.05% upon excitation at 273 nm. The lifetime for λem = 402 nm is 1.82(4) ns. Because both emission and excitation profiles of solid 2 are in agreement with those of H6L2, the purple emission of solid 2 may be assigned to the ligand-centered π–π* transition. The emission peak of solid 2 shows a 41 nm bathochromic shift in comparison with that of H6L2. Furthermore, the purple emission of solid 2 can be preserved after compound 2 is heated at 160 °C for 2 h under an air atmosphere. This result is in accord with the observation that the 3D framework of solid 2 is stable up to 160 °C under an air atmosphere.

elements.content: The theoretical ion-exchange capacity of solid 1 is 2.097 mequiv g–1. ICP measurements reveal that the contents of Ag+, Li+, and Eu3+ in solids 1-Ag, 1-Li, and 1-Eu are 0.151, 0.30, and 0.037 mmol g–1, respectively. Correspondingly, the C content of solids 1-Ag, 1-Li, and 1-Eu is less than that of as-prepared 1. These results indicate that partial protonated 2-methylpiperazine in solid 1 can be exchanged by Ag+, Li+, and Eu3+ cations, which reach 7.2, 14, and 5.3% of the total ion-exchange capacity, respectively. Powder XRD patterns of solids 1-Ag, 1-Li, and 1-Eu are in agreement with those of as-prepared 1, indicating that the framework of solid 1 remains in its original form after ion exchanging with Ag+, Li+, and Eu3+ cations. Similar to solid 1, solids 1-Ag, 1-Li, and 1-Eu can also display near-UV luminescence with maximal bands around 377 nm. It worth noting that the luminescent intensity of solid 1-Ag can be irreversibly weakened by UV irradiation (). For instance, after irradiation with UV radiation at 290 nm for 5 min, the luminescent intensity of solid 1-Ag can be weakened to 30%. Meanwhile, the color of solid 1-Ag changed from white to black. It is well-known that excessive exposure to UV radiation causes skin cancer, cataracts, and other eye diseases. In particular, the eyes are most sensitive to UV radiation with a wavelength of ∼280 nm. Because UV radiation is invisible to stimulate the natural defenses of the eyes, facile synthesis and thermal stability make solid 1-Ag an attractive material to be used for the sensing of UV radiation.
elements.clean_text:
Ion Exchange

The theoretical ion-exchange capacity of solid 1 is 2.097 mequiv g-1. ICP measurements reveal that the contents of Ag+, Li+, and Eu3+ in solids 1-Ag, 1-Li, and 1-Eu are 0.151, 0.30, and 0.037 mmol g-1, respectively. Correspondingly, the C content of solids 1-Ag, 1-Li, and 1-Eu is less than that of as-prepared 1. These results indicate that partial protonated 2-methylpiperazine in solid 1 can be exchanged by Ag+, Li+, and Eu3+ cations, which reach 7.2, 14, and 5.3% of the total ion-exchange capacity, respectively. Powder XRD patterns of solids 1-Ag, 1-Li, and 1-Eu are in agreement with those of as-prepared 1, indicating that the framework of solid 1 remains in its original form after ion exchanging with Ag+, Li+, and Eu3+ cations. Similar to solid 1, solids 1-Ag, 1-Li, and 1-Eu can also display near-UV luminescence with maximal bands around 377 nm. It worth noting that the luminescent intensity of solid 1-Ag can be irreversibly weakened by UV irradiation (). For instance, after irradiation with UV radiation at 290 nm for 5 min, the luminescent intensity of solid 1-Ag can be weakened to 30%. Meanwhile, the color of solid 1-Ag changed from white to black. It is well-known that excessive exposure to UV radiation causes skin cancer, cataracts, and other eye diseases. In particular, the eyes are most sensitive to UV radiation with a wavelength of ~280 nm. Because UV radiation is invisible to stimulate the natural defenses of the eyes, facile synthesis and thermal stability make solid 1-Ag an attractive material to be used for the sensing of UV radiation.

Powder XRD patterns of solid 1-Cu are also in accord with those of as-prepared 1, indicating that the framework of solid 1 remains in its original form after ion exchanging with the Cu2+ cation, and no emission of 1-Cu can be detected in our experiment.

elements.content: On the basis of new functionalized phosphonate ligands, two 3D zinc phosphonates, namely, [(C5H14N2)­Zn3(HL1)­(H2O)]·3.5H2O (1) and [(C5H14N2)­Zn2L2]·3H2O (2), have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. Both compounds 1 and 2 are interesting 3D frameworks containing protonated 2-methylpiperazine. TGA and powder XRD reveal that 3D frameworks of compounds 1 and 2 are thermally stable up to 200 and 160 °C under an air atmosphere, respectively. Solids 1 and 2 display near-UV and purple luminescence, respectively. It worth noting that the luminescence of solids 1 and 2 can be preserved after compounds 1 and 2 are heated at 200 and 160 °C, respectively, for 2 h under an air atmosphere. Furthermore, solid 1 exhibits an ion-exchange property maintaining the integrity of the framework. In future, we will try to synthesize other functionalized phosphonic acids by a combination of a triazine ring with the N­(CH2COOH) (CH2PO3H2) moiety, along with amino acids, such as proline and alanine. Then, such functionalized phosphonate ligands will be exploited to prepare new metal phosphonates with interesting structures and to investigate their properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

On the basis of new functionalized phosphonate ligands, two 3D zinc phosphonates, namely, [(C5H14N2)Zn3(HL1)(H2O)]⋅3.5H2O (1) and [(C5H14N2)Zn2L2]⋅3H2O (2), have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. Both compounds 1 and 2 are interesting 3D frameworks containing protonated 2-methylpiperazine. TGA and powder XRD reveal that 3D frameworks of compounds 1 and 2 are thermally stable up to 200 and 160 °C under an air atmosphere, respectively. Solids 1 and 2 display near-UV and purple luminescence, respectively. It worth noting that the luminescence of solids 1 and 2 can be preserved after compounds 1 and 2 are heated at 200 and 160 °C, respectively,  for 2 h under an air atmosphere. Furthermore, solid 1 exhibits an ion-exchange property maintaining the integrity of the framework. In future, we will try to synthesize other functionalized phosphonic acids by a combination of a triazine ring with the N(CH2COOH) (CH2PO3H2) moiety, along with amino acids, such as proline and alanine. Then, such functionalized phosphonate ligands will be exploited to prepare new metal phosphonates with interesting structures and to investigate their properties.

A mixture of Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.1021 g, 0.4651 mmol), H9L1 (0.0591 g, 0.102 mmol), and 2-methylpiperazine (1.00 g, 9.98 mmol) in 8.0 mL of distilled water with the pH value adjusted to around 3.9 was sealed in a Parr Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 110 °C for 120 h. After the sample had been slowly cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals were obtained as a homogeneous phase based on powder XRD patterns. Yield: 0.0254 g (26%). Anal. Calcd for C17H36N8O19.5P3Zn3: C, 21.41; H, 3.81; N, 11.75. Found: C, 21.86; H, 3.85; N, 11.33. Synthesis of [(C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>14</sub>N<sub>2</sub>)­Zn<sub>2</sub>L2]·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.1235 g, 0.5626 mmol), H6L2 (0.0703 g, 0.163 mmol), and 2-methylpiperazine (0.2242 g, 2.238 mmol) in 6.0 mL of distilled water with the pH value adjusted to around 3.5 was sealed in a Parr Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 120 °C for 40 h. After the sample had been slowly cooled to room temperature, pure orange crystals were manually separated from a small amount of unknown white powder. The pure orange crystals of 2 were obtained as a homogeneous phase based on powder XRD patterns. Yield: 0.0500 g (43%). Anal. Calcd for C14H29N7O14P2Zn2: C, 23.61; H, 4.10; N, 13.77. Found: C, 23.09; H, 4.20; N, 13.27. IR (KBr pellet): 3512m, 3458s, 3221w, 3140w, 3005w, 2961w, 1657m, 1630m, 1526s, 1387m, 1325w, 1290m, 1165m, 1123s, 976m, 854w, 806m, 729m, 669w, 554m cm–1.

Ion-Exchange ExperimentSynthesis of <bold>1-Ag</bold>

Newly synthesized powder of 1 (0.0281 g, 0.0295 mmol) was added to a solution containing AgNO3 (0.1690 g, 1.00 mmol) and 5.0 mL of ethanol. Then, the mixture was sealed into a Parr Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 80 °C for 20 h. After the sample had been cooled to room temperature, the final product was filtered, washed with 3 × 50 mL of distilled water and then 3 × 50 mL of ethanol, and dried at ambient temperature. ICP analysis shows that the content of Ag+ in solid 1-Ag is 0.151 mmol g–1. Elemental analyses: C, 20.34; H, 3.72; N, 11.26.

Synthesis of <bold>1-Li</bold>

Newly synthesized powder of 1 (0.0304 g, 0.0319 mmol) was added to a solution containing LiCl·H2O (0.0610 g, 1.01 mmol) and 6.0 mL of ethanol. Then, the mixture was sealed in a Parr Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 80 °C for 20 h. After the sample had been cooled to room temperature, the final product was filtered, washed with 2 × 50 mL of distilled water and then 2 × 50 mL of ethanol, and dried under ambient temperature. ICP analysis shows that the content of Li+ in solid 1-Li is 0.30 mmol g–1. Elemental analyses: C, 21.08; H, 3.48; N, 11.57.

Synthesis of <bold>1-Eu</bold>

Newly synthesized powder of 1 (0.0314 g, 0.0329 mmol) was added to a solution containing Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.4560 g, 1.022 mmol) and 6.0 mL of ethanol. Then, the mixture was sealed in a Parr Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 80 °C for 20 h. After the sample had been been cooled to room temperature, the final product was filtered, washed with 2 × 50 mL of distilled water and then 2 × 50 mL of ethanol, and dried at ambient temperature. ICP analysis shows that the content of Eu3+ in solid 1-Eu is 0.037 mmol g–1. Elemental analyses: C, 20.94; H, 3.88; N, 11.56.

Synthesis of <bold>1-Cu</bold>

Newly synthesized powder of 1 (0.0414 g, 0.0434 mmol) was soaked in a solution containing CuCl2·2H2O (1.7004 g, 9.9771 mmol) and 5.0 mL of distilled water for 18 days. The color of the powder turned from white into green. After filtration, the green powder was washed with a vast amount of distilled water until the filter liquor was colorless and then dried at ambient temperature. ICP analysis shows that the content of Cu2+ in solid 1-Cu is 1.803 mmol g–1. Elemental analyses: C, 17.72; H, 3.76; N, 9.94.

Found: C, 23.09; H, 4.20; N, 13.27. IR (KBr pellet): 3512m, 3458s, 3221w, 3140w, 3005w, 2961w, 1657m, 1630m, 1526s, 1387m, 1325w, 1290m, 1165m, 1123s, 976m, 854w, 806m, 729m, 669w, 554m cm-1.

Ion-Exchange Experiment

Synthesis of 1-Ag 

Newly synthesized powder of 1 (0.0281 g, 0.0295 mmol) was added to a solution containing AgNO3 (0.1690 g, 1.00 mmol) and 5.0 mL of ethanol. Then, the mixture was sealed into a Parr Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 80 °C for 20 h. After the sample had been cooled to room temperature, the final product was filtered, washed with 3 × 50 mL of distilled water and then 3 × 50 mL of ethanol, and dried at ambient temperature. ICP analysis shows that the content of Ag+ in solid 1-Ag is 0.151 mmol g-1. Elemental analyses: C, 20.34; H, 3.72; N, 11.26.

Synthesis of 1-Li 

Newly synthesized powder of 1 (0.0304 g, 0.0319 mmol) was added to a solution containing LiCl⋅H2O (0.0610 g, 1.01 mmol) and 6.0 mL of ethanol. Then, the mixture was sealed in a Parr Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 80 °C for 20 h. After the sample had been cooled to room temperature, the final product was filtered, washed with 2 × 50 mL of distilled water and then 2 × 50 mL of ethanol, and dried under ambient temperature. ICP analysis shows that the content of Li+ in solid 1-Li is 0.30 mmol g-1. Elemental analyses: C, 21.08; H, 3.48; N, 11.57.

Synthesis of 1-Eu 

Newly synthesized powder of 1 (0.0314 g, 0.0329 mmol) was added to a solution containing Eu(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.4560 g, 1.022 mmol) and 6.0 mL of ethanol. Then, the mixture was sealed in a Parr Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 80 °C for 20 h. After the sample had been been cooled to room temperature, the final product was filtered, washed with 2 × 50 mL of distilled water and then 2 × 50 mL of ethanol, and dried at ambient temperature. ICP analysis shows that the content of Eu3+ in solid 1-Eu is 0.037 mmol g-1. Elemental analyses: C, 20.94; H, 3.88; N, 11.56.

Synthesis of 1-Cu 

Newly synthesized powder of 1 (0.0414 g, 0.0434 mmol) was soaked in a solution containing CuCl2⋅2H2O (1.7004 g, 9.9771 mmol) and 5.0 mL of distilled water for 18 days. The color of the powder turned from white into green. After filtration, the green powder was washed with a vast amount of distilled water until the filter liquor was colorless and then dried at ambient temperature. ICP analysis shows that the content of Cu2+ in solid 1-Cu is 1.803 mmol g-1. Elemental analyses: C, 17.72; H, 3.76; N, 9.94.

cln_elements.content:
TGA and powder XRD measurements were taken to examine thermal stabilities (). For solid 1, an obvious stage occurs from room temperature to 150 °C with a 10.5% weight loss, which is attributed to the loss of 4.5 water molecules per formula (calculated value of 9.1%). When the sample is heated further, small weight losses appear until an abrupt stage starts from 290 °C due to the decomposition of the HL18– anion and the protonated 2-methylpiperazine. As a result, the 3D framework collapses. A TGA curve of solid 2 indicates that there is an obvious stage in the temperature range of 40–160 °C with a 7.87% observed weight loss, which corresponds with the release of three free water molecules per formula (calculated value of 7.58%). Then, the subsequent weight loss over 300 °C is assigned to the decomposition of the L26– anion and the protonated 2-methylpiperazine, resulting in the collapse of the 3D framework. Furthermore, powder XRD patterns of solids 1-200 and 2-160 are essentially in agreement with those of as-prepared 1 and 2, respectively. These results indicate that the 3D frameworks of compounds 1 and 2 are stable up to 200 and 160 °C, respectively, under an air atmosphere.

Luminescenct Properties

Solid-state luminescent properties were investigated at ambient temperature. Solid 1 displays near-ultraviolet (UV) luminescence with a maximal band at 377 nm (). The external quantum yield reaches 2.9% upon excitation at 293 nm. Because both emission and excitation profiles of solid 1 are similar to those of H9L1, the UV emission of solid 1 may be assigned to a ligand-centered π–π* transition. The emission peak of solid 1 shows a 17 nm bathochromic shift in comparison with that of H9L1. Solid 1-200 can also display similar UV emission with a maximal band at 363 nm. This result is in accord with the observation that the 3D framework of solid 1 is stable up to 200 °C under an air atmosphere. Although the structure of solid 1-250 disagrees with that of as-prepared 1, solid 1-250 can also emit similar near-UV luminescence. This indicates that the near-UV luminescence can be preserved after compound 1 is heated at 250 °C for 2 h under an air atmosphere. In addition, solid 1 can display more strong near-UV luminescence with a maximal band at 367 nm at 10 K.

Solid 2 displays purple luminescence with a maximal band at 402 nm via excitation at 273 nm (). The external quantum yield reaches 9.05% upon excitation at 273 nm. The lifetime for λem = 402 nm is 1.82(4) ns. Because both emission and excitation profiles of solid 2 are in agreement with those of H6L2, the purple emission of solid 2 may be assigned to the ligand-centered π–π* transition. The emission peak of solid 2 shows a 41 nm bathochromic shift in comparison with that of H6L2. Furthermore, the purple emission of solid 2 can be preserved after compound 2 is heated at 160 °C for 2 h under an air atmosphere. This result is in accord with the observation that the 3D framework of solid 2 is stable up to 160 °C under an air atmosphere.

In contrast to the low metal contents of solids 1-Ag, 1-Li, and 1-Eu, the content of Cu2+ in solid 1-Cu reaches 1.803 mmol g–1. Powder XRD patterns of solid 1-Cu are also in accord with those of as-prepared 1, indicating that the framework of solid 1 remains in its original form after ion exchanging with the Cu2+ cation, and no emission of 1-Cu can be detected in our experiment.
